qas.question: When did farmers build a bridge over the Harlem River?
Why did farmers build a bridge over the Harlem River?
What strategic advantage did the Bronx's location have?

answers.text: between New England and New York

context: The development of the Bronx is directly connected to its strategic location <a2_0>between New England and New York<a2_0/> (Manhattan). Control over the bridges across the Harlem River plagued the period of British colonial rule. Kingsbridge, built in <a3_0>1693<a3_0/> where Broadway reached the Spuyten Duyvil Creek, was a possession of <a4_0>Frederick Philipse<a4_0/>, lord of Philipse Manor. The <a1_0>tolls were resented<a1_0/> by local farmers on both sides of the creek. In <a0_0>1759<a0_0/>, the farmers led by Jacobus Dyckman and Benjamin Palmer built a "free bridge" across the Harlem River which led to the abandonment of tolls altogether.
